text:
Loved seeing ya go through this Gura, you made the right choice playing on Human mode.

You're jumping into a series that's had 5 games to grow in complexity so Dante and Nero are at their peaks, add in V and you've got a whole mess of play styles and mechanics. ( you hardly used Devil Trigger at all haha)

I feel it may have hampered your enjoyment if you had started on Devil Hunter which would be a shame. Now that things are starting to fall into place for you, you should be fine for future games.

I look forward to you gaining, losing then regaining MOTIVATION against Vergil in DMC 3!!

author: @S.A.O.D.A

text:
DMC5 had such a universal hype train going for it on release and watching Gura play through it has been the only thing to come close to matching that joy again. Thank you so much Gura, this run has become special one to me. Your happiness is infectious as always and I finally got a glimpse into how people in the 80s reacted to the Star Wars "I am your father scene" before it became so widely known :_GuraHAHA:

Just a note on DMC3 if people want to try it: Originally 3 made you pick a style to use at the start of a mission and you had to stick with it, but the Switch release of the game has a feature that lets you change between styles, like you could in 5. The PC version has DMC 1, 2 and 3 as part of the DMC HD collection, which looks prettier but you need to use a mod if you want to style swap.

text:
For those who never played this game...

Here's some notes on things that happened and didn't happen (I'm not trying to be mean to Gura at all, I'm just explaining stuff):

- Gura wasn't letting go of the button to target enemies (R1), so when she was trying to turn the camera, it'd snap back into place. That's why she was getting frustrated with the camera. 
- She wasn't letting go of the button to target enemies (R1), so when the game told her "Press RT to grab enemies" she was actually pressing R1+RT which is the function to simply pull enemies towards you. So she missed out on Nero actually doing epic grab combos on Vergil.
- Because Gura rarely ever stopped targeting (holding R1), she RARELY ever used Nero's arms/Devil Breakers, which are his go-to for crazy moves. He can do stuff like stop time, use enemies like meat-shields, or even ride his rocket arm. It's a shame she missed out on that.
- As Nero, Gura was at times constantly mashing L1, which is the function to DETONATE Nero's arm (Devil Breaker), destroying it but allowing Nero to repel any enemy attack. 
- As Nero, if he is hit while using any of the Devil Breaker functions... the arm is destroyed on the spot. Between this and Gura mashing L1 to destroy the Devil Breakers herself, it's why Gura was often without any Devil Breakers to use.
- Sadly, the taunt button was never pressed once. There's a crazy fun taunt system that helps raises you style meter all the way from D to SSS, and the taunts get more crazy per level. There's awesome stuff like Nero air guitaring or V air... violining~
- To better raise your style and achieve SSS (which gets you many more orbs to spend): don't get hit and don't spam the exact same attacks over and over. If you couldn't tell, Gura was spamming constantly so she never broke S rank.
- Those poor under-used pistols of Dante's. 
- Gura didn't realize that with V, if Shadow or Griffin take too much damage and become orbs, the way to restore them faster is to stand near them.
- Lore. Tons of lore. Wanna know more? Devil May Cry 1, 3, and 4 are still great games to play~
- We don't talk about 2.

I'm happy Gura had fun, but a lot was unfortunately missed. Oh well~ So, if you venture to play this game yourself, there's still plenty of content to see and hav fun with! Hopefully seeing this will help you be better prepared to kick some demon ash~

text:
¬†@ToxicVex267¬† Of course, it's pretty much confirmed that they are equals. However Dante wins when it matters and grows to match Vergil every time because he has something to fight for, people he cares about. In comparison Vergil only fights for himself, sure he had a solid reason to get strong in the beginning but his view clearly warped from "I gotta get strong so I can no longer be hurt" to "I don't care who I hurt, as long as I gain more power". The former being a more selfish version of Nero's own reason for gaining strength, which is "I need power so I can protect the people close to me" the difference is still very noticeable of course, Nero wants power to protect what he holds dear and Vergil wants power so he can't be hurt anymore.

This is ultimately the reason Vergil loses the major battles in the end, and I'm pretty sure he could've killed Dante several times, but decided not to. No idea if that is because he still felt a connection to his little brother or if it was in respect to their parents but whatever the case is it doesn't really matter.
author: @TheArrivalCyberse

text:
¬†@TheArrivalCyberse¬† and that‚Äôs the beauty of Vs development in devil may cry 5. Since he tried so hard to protect his human half from ever getting hurt he never allowed it to experience anything. But by forcing his humanity out it allowed it to experience life and also reflect on his past decisions cause of this development something happened that a good portion of dmc fans noticed Vergil has changed.

See this Vergil is different from the old Vergil because he actually starts questioning his life choices and wondering if his life could have been different if Eva found him first something the old Vergil would have just suppressed. Not mention he‚Äôs no longer suffering from his pats trauma cause the embodiment of it decided they‚Äôd rather die then let Vergil go threw it again which was a beautiful scene. Even his fight with Dante is somewhat different from passed fights while some people saw it as Vergil still wanting to kill Dante if you look Vergil is actually having fun in The fight but I believe the biggest change comes in his fight with Nero for years Vergil has followed his fathers shadow but having his own son opposing his ideals and winning was a wake up call for Vergil. and in the end he and Dante are still fighting but it‚Äôs different they‚Äôre both smiling more actually talking to each other not as enemies but as brothers

text: To be fair, virtually EVERY single person who hasn't played this series before did the EXACT same thing in this part. I even called it out myself saying "how much do you bet she'll spam Snatch instead of doing Buster?". People get confused for some reason and don't realize that you have to let go of R1 for it to work.
author: @zffrailgun1630

text: ¬†@zffrailgun1630¬† But pressing a trigger with the middle finger feels awkward! I'm amazed people instinctively press both R1 and R2 instead of moving their index finger down to R2.
author: @rikamayhem

text: ¬†@rikamayhem¬† I personally have no issue pressing R2 with my middle finger as it's a requirement for a lot of games besides DMC, like shooters. As for why people press both buttons, it's pretty simple. They want to stay locked on to the target but don't understand that locking on changes the way you access certain moves or completely removes the ability to use moves. Good players will let go of R1 for a split second to input R2 and then immediately press it again (obviously using both the index and middle fingers because it's faster).
author: @zffrailgun1630

text:
¬†@zffrailgun1630¬† I mean, I can and have done it too, but it definitely wouldn't be my first instinct. I see it as an unnatural grip, just less than a claw grip.

But I'd like evidence that's it's faster to use the middle finger (not asking you to provide it). There're studies about how middle fingers have the slowest reaction times, IIRC because they're generally used to support the other fingers rather than independently. It is a skill that can be trained, but to a degree that makes a difference? I'm not sure.
author: @rikamayhem

text: ¬†Peco peco¬† Uhh how are the controls in 3 any more jank than 4/5 when it's all the same control scheme aside from style switching. The inputs are near identical. If anything you have more control in 3 than 5 because you can still do reversals and it doesn't have 5's awful camera.
author: @Gamegalgegod

text: ¬†@rikamayhem¬† When your finger is already on a button that you want to press, it would obviously take significantly less time to do so than removing your other finger from another button, going over to the other button and pressing it, it's simple logic. I'm not sure it would take any particular training unless you are uncomfortable holding the controller that way, which kinda doesn't make sense with the way the PS and XB controllers are designed. It would also make you completely unable to perform certain actions if you had to use your index over your middle finger every time.
author: @zffrailgun1630

text: ¬†@Gamegalgegod¬† Controls in DMC3 aren't "jank" but they are definitely worse than DMC5 due to how certain mechanics were changed. Take Air Trick for example, I recently went to it and realized that I can't do Air Trick off of Sky Star until Dante stopped, landed and turned around, while the interaction in 5 is much more fluid and faster. Also, reversals have nothing to do with the game being "jank" or not and they have almost no practical application to combat other than combo videos. And to close it off, DMC5's camera is in no way, shape or form worse than DMC3's. In fact, DMC3's is the worse camera here since it mostly uses the fixed camera, while DMC5's is free and can be directly controlled by the player.
author: @zffrailgun1630

text:
¬†@zffrailgun1630¬† Yes, I agree certain interactions in 3 Vs 5 like what you described are definitely an improvement. Also agree reversals in itself are not relevant to the jankiness of the games so my mistake on that one, don't really agree on your assessment of their use at all. Reversals have complete practicality, it increases your movement options significantly. Boiling it down to it only has uses in combos is not seeing what reversals add for people to improve their movement options. You can reversal high time if an enemy is facing behind you without having to manually turn and switch the lock on, or use the back-dash portion of shuffle to evade an enemy attack to then hit them if they're outside your lock-on.

Bruh what game are you playing to say 5's camera is an overall improvement to the game, you lose lock on frequently if you even remotely gain too much air, plenty of people have experienced the lock on fucking up their combos or movement putting them in situations where they get hit. You don't get that in 3 or 4. Your inputs don't get eaten by the camera at all. Yes I agree the freedom of movement for the camera in-between fights in 5 is much better but when it comes to combat that camera is an absolute detriment when enemies start to stack up on you.
author: @Gamegalgegod

text:
¬†@Gamegalgegod¬† Thing is, since locking on is pretty much instant and sets the direction of the character to where you're locked on, even if your model hasn't turned, you can still perform those actions and have the same result. Reversals make so little difference when the game is optimized that way that it doesn't matter in the grand scheme of things. 

I'm playing the same game as everyone else. The only point that the camera has an issue is when you're not locked on. The moment you lock on, you get a wide-shot view and everything becomes perfectly fine. Even without locking on, since your camera is free, you can move it wherever you want, though it's nowhere near as optimal as using lock on. All in all, the camera is a massive improvement over any of the previous games and throughout all my playthroughs I have never encountered an issue with it.
author: @zffrailgun1630

text:
¬†@zffrailgun1630¬†   If you have two enemies, one in front and one behind, you cannot perform a shuffle to hit both enemies without a reversal. Like, you cannot perform a reversal and net the same result with the lock-on, it's objectively not possible, nothing in the game replaces a reversal. Your streak/stinger will target the enemy if you lock on, you can't streak away from an enemy to escape an attack. The only moves that allow reversals with enemies are an exceed streak or performing a full weapon rotation whilst doing stinger/backslide in vanilla. I agree in the grand scheme for a majority of players reversals won't see much use but for dedicated players it pays back in spades with the value it gives you. 

Yeah the game allows you to have a wide angle view for the camera which is an improvement, but the game also does a bad job following you once you start performing JC's too high in tight small arenas or making you break lock on and switching targets mid combo, it happens frequently to so many people, there's a fix in the cheat table for this specific reason. DMC4 or 3 does not give you this issue at all, the lock on is completely consistent for you. Like, there's early footage of Vergil in DMC5SE doing rapid slash in the prologue and the camera is spazzing the fuck out like crazy. You don't get this at all in 3/4.
author: @Gamegalgegod

text:
And now we are at the end of the game, so let‚Äôs wrap it up with the last few DMC facts!

- Urizen‚Äôs attacks in mission 17 are reminiscent of Beowulf‚Äôs moveset in DMC3 (Beowulf being the punch-and-kick weapon)

- Griffon and Nightmare were bosses back in DMC1, and Shadow was a miniboss/enhanced enemy. The Visions of V manga show V trying to summon Phantom, the first boss of DMC1; however, because Phantom was an asshole who didn‚Äôt want to listen, he got discarded instantly.

- In DMC4, it‚Äôs never explicitly stated that Nero is Vergil‚Äôs son. The art book is the first source that says it.

- By completing the game, Nero now has the ability to perform a buster attack (R2 while unlocked) at all times. However, it‚Äôs only half as strong as the Devil Breaker variant.

- Nero‚Äôs Devil Trigger is reminiscent of his concept DT form from the fourth game.

- In the cutscene after mission 18, three of the four people in the van had their dads killed by Dante.

- There are two difficulties known as ‚ÄúHeaven and Hell‚Äù and ‚ÄúHell and Hell.‚Äù In Heaven and Hell, everything (including you) dies in one hit. In Hell and Hell, only you die in one hit.

- Vergil‚Äôs Doppelg√§nger and Dante‚Äôs ‚ÄúNot in a million years‚Äù line are references to the reboot game.

- Nero has an air taunt where he uses his sword as a skateboard. It‚Äôs possible to ex-act or even max-act the taunt.

- In the final battle, the main buster attack has Nero clash with Vergil before Yamato gets jammed into Vergil‚Äôs gut. It‚Äôs possible to time the attack so the sword clashes line up with the lyrics ‚Äúget closer.‚Äù

- The final boss theme, ‚ÄúSilver Bullet,‚Äù is Nero‚Äôs boss theme.
